title: SGX proposes to slash board‑lot sizes for higher‑priced stocks to make trading more affordable for retail investors
body: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) plans to reduce standard board‑lot sizes from 100 to 10 units for stocks priced between $10 and $100 and to one unit for stocks above $100, lowering the minimum investment from a few thousand dollars to a few hundred dollars, with the proposal open for comment until Feb 13 and implementation targeted for mid‑2026. Analysts at Phillip Securities, UOB Kay Hian, RHB Singapore and Morningstar welcomed the move as a catalyst for retail trading growth, while noting potential liquidity fragmentation and broader structural challenges.

title: The Assembly Place Shares Surge on Singapore Exchange Debut
body: The Assembly Place debuted on the Singapore Exchange with its shares surging 34.8 percent above its IPO price to 31 cents, following a public offer that was 35.5 times subscribed and reporting FY2024 revenue of $18.9 million and a net profit of $6.2 million. Cornerstone investors such as Apricot Capital, Asdew Acquisitions, Cache Capital, ICH Synergrowth Fund, and Maybank Securities subscribed for approximately 29.5 million shares, as The Assembly Place became the second Singapore company to list on SGX in 2026, following Toku, with Concord New Energy also having a secondary listing.

title: SGX Maintains Integrated Multi-Asset Strategy Amid Strong Growth in Cash Equities and Record Derivatives Performance
body: SGX affirmed its multi-asset strategy, declining to decouple its cash equities and derivatives businesses, despite the Singapore stock market's revival seeing December 2025 trading value rise 29% to $25.8 billion. Concurrently, SGX's derivatives business achieved record volumes in 2025, with trading up 10% to 329 million contracts, and RHB Bank Singapore forecasts continued strong growth across all segments.

title: Toku Shares Surge on Catalist Debut, Raising $16.3 Million for Expansion
body: Toku, an AI-based cloud communications service provider, debuted on the Catalist board with shares surging 14 per cent to 28.5 cents, after opening 4 per cent above its IPO price and raising approximately $16.3 million in gross proceeds. The company, which focuses on Asia-Pacific, reported revenue growth from US$21.6 million in financial year 2022 to US$31.8 million in financial year 2024, despite widening losses, and plans to use the funds for platform expansion and tech development.

title: Seven Singapore-Listed Companies, Including Coliwoo, Recognized Among Republic's Fastest-Growing Firms
body: Seven Singapore-listed companies, namely iFast Corporation, iX Biopharma, Rex International, CSE Global, Coliwoo, Parkway Hospitals Singapore, and AIMS APAC, are among the Republic's 100 fastest-growing firms, based on high revenue growth between 2021 and 2024. Coliwoo, a spin-off from LHN Group and making its debut on the list, plans to launch new co-living accommodations adding 594 rooms, expand its portfolio by 800 to 1,000 rooms annually towards a target of about 4,000 rooms, and increase its workforce in 2026.

title: Singapore Launches $30 Million Program to Boost Listed Companies' Valuations and Investor Engagement
body: Singapore announced a $30 million Value Unlock program on January 16 to help its listed companies enhance valuations and investor engagement through two grants. Administered by Singapore Exchange (SGX) and complementing efforts by Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Singapore Institute of Directors (SID), the program offers Equip and Elevate grants covering 50% of fees up to $15,000 and $200,000 respectively, with specific market capitalization criteria for the Elevate grant.

title: Singapore Launches New Guild and Academy to Enhance Corporate Governance and Board Leadership
body: The Singapore Institute of Directors (SID) launched a new Chairpersons Guild and a board academy on January 16, supported by SGX and the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), to enhance corporate governance and leadership for board chairpersons of Singapore-listed companies. These initiatives, which include programs co-curated with Heidrick & Struggles, McKinsey & Company, and UBS, aim to strengthen Singapore's equities market by fostering strong leadership and capability-building.

title: JP Morgan Asset Management Launches New Income-Focused Fund with Significant Allocation to Singapore and Asian Equities
body: JP Morgan Asset Management has launched the Singapore and Asia Equity Income Fund, allocating 50 per cent of its capital to Singapore-listed stocks and the remaining 50 per cent to Asian stocks excluding Japan, resulting in an overall Singapore stock weightage of approximately 53 per cent. Part of the Monetary Authority of Singapore's $5 billion Equity Market Development Programme, this income-focused fund uses dividend-paying stocks and options, and was launched after Avanda Investment Management and Fullerton Fund Management introduced their respective EQDP funds.

title: The Assembly Place Aims to Raise $18.3 Million in SGX IPO to Expand Co-Living Portfolio to 10,000 Rooms by 2030
body: The Assembly Place (TAP) is conducting an Initial Public Offering (IPO) on the SGX Catalist board to raise $18.3 million, with funds primarily allocated to expanding its co-living portfolio to 10,000 rooms by 2030 and for working capital. SAC Capital is the sponsor for the IPO, which has cornerstone investors including Apricot Capital, Asdew Acquisitions, Cache Capital, ICH Synergrowth Fund, and Maybank Securities, while TAP itself reported $18.9 million in revenue and a net profit of $6.2 million for FY2024.

title: Singapore Stock Market Experiences Stellar 2025 Driven by Record Retail Inflows and Strong Performance
body: The Singapore stock market experienced a stellar 2025, with retail investors contributing a five-year high of $2.62 billion in net inflows, significantly boosting banks such as DBS, UOB, and OCBC, alongside Mapletree Industrial Trust and NTT DC Reit. The Straits Times Index achieved a record high and 28.8% total returns, while new listings included UltraGreenai Limited, Infinity Development Holdings Company, and Leong Guan Holdings, despite net outflows from CDL and other non-bank stocks.

title: Singapore Proposes Rule Changes to Streamline Dual Listings with US Nasdaq
body: The Monetary Authority of Singapore and Singapore Exchange Regulation are proposing rule changes to streamline the IPO process for companies seeking dual listings on the SGX and Nasdaq, with the Global Listing Board (GLB) targeted for mid-2026. These proposals, welcomed by Securities Investors Association Singapore (Sias) but also noted for potential challenges by Legal Solutions, include requirements for GLB eligibility such as a minimum $2 billion market capitalisation and allocating 5% or $50 million of the offering to retail investors.

title: Singapore and Nasdaq Partner for Streamlined Dual Listing Initiative Launching Mid-2026
body: Singapore is set to launch a Global Listing Board initiative by mid-2026, enabling companies to list simultaneously on the SGX and Nasdaq using a single prospectus to streamline the process and attract broader capital. While welcomed by companies such as Carro, Carsome, Funding Societies, and Hummingbird Bioscience, the initiative faces banker cautions regarding Singapore's thin liquidity and a high $2 billion market value threshold, despite the city-state's IPOs raising US$2.15 billion in 2025.

title: Cordlife's Restricted Licence Renewal Boosts Shares Amidst Ongoing Client Claims
body: Cordlife received a one-year restricted licence renewal from the Ministry of Health, allowing it to store and transfer existing cord blood, which led to its shares surging over 18 per cent. Concurrently, Cordlife has applied to convert client claims totaling at least $5.45 million into an "originating claim," potentially moving the dispute to a full trial with a negative financial impact if ordered to pay this financial year.

title: Cordlife Renews Key Licences and Updates on $5.45 Million Legal Claims Amidst Regulatory Compliance
body: Cordlife has secured a one-year renewal for its cord blood banking service licence, permitting storage and transfer of existing units but not new collections, and a two-year renewal for its human tissue banking licence, with a new regulatory condition requiring viability testing for cord blood unit release. The company also announced an update on legal claims totaling at least $5.45 million, stating that payment of these claims this financial year would negatively impact its financial position.

title: Singapore Exchange Discusses Introducing Futures for Asian Government Bonds
body: Singapore Exchange has held preliminary discussions with global banks about introducing futures tied to government bond markets in India, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, and Thailand, with a target launch in the first half of 2026. These US dollar-settled futures would offer three-, five-, and 10-year maturities, reflecting growing interest in the region's debt markets, including US$21 billion poured into Indian sovereign bonds since their inclusion in JPMorgan Chase's flagship index in June 2024, as highlighted by Mr Rajeev De Mello from Gama Asset Management.

title: Singapore Stock Market Begins 2026 with Strong Gains Driven by Banking, Property, and Increased IPO Activity
body: Singapore's stock market experienced a brisk start to 2026, with banking stocks like DBS Group, OCBC Bank, and UOB leading gains and property developers City Developments, Hongkong Land, and UOL also performing strongly, propelling the Straits Times Index to new highs. Singapore Exchange saw a significant rise in 2025 trading value and IPOs, including the debut of Concord New Energy and the upcoming listing of UI Boustead real estate investment trust, while Digital Core REIT secured a major lease and Nam Cheong saw an uptick.

title: Geopolitical Tensions Drive Market Volatility, Boosting Gold and Bitcoin While Highlighting Singapore Investment Opportunities in 2026
body: Financial markets in 2026 began with volatility driven by heightened geopolitical tensions, leading Gold prices to rise to US$4,470 per ounce and Bitcoin to show resilience, hitting over US$93,000, with BlackRock's iShares Bitcoin Trust recording US$287.4 million in inflows and total US spot Bitcoin ETF flows at US$471 million. Amid these shifts, OCBC, CGS International Securities, OKX Singapore, and Morningstar highlight Gold's growing safe haven role, Bitcoin's use as a hedging tool, and opportunities in Singapore's stock market and REITs, including Keppel REIT, Mapletree Industrial Trust, CapitaLand Ascendas REIT, CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust, Keppel DC REIT, Parkway Life REIT, and OUE REIT.

title: The Assembly Place's IPO 35.5 Times Subscribed Ahead of Catalist Debut
body: Co-living operator The Assembly Place's initial public offering on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board was 35.5 times subscribed for its public offer, raising net proceeds of S$10.8 million from gross proceeds of S$18.3 million. The subscription exercise, which included cornerstone investors such as Apricot Capital, Asdew Acquisitions, and Cache Capital, gives the company an estimated market capitalisation of S$88.1 million ahead of its trading debut on Friday.

title: UI Boustead REIT plans Singapore listing targeting at least $900 million
body: UI Boustead real estate investment trust, a unit of Boustead Singapore, is gearing up for a Singapore listing as early as March, targeting proceeds of at least $900 million. Boustead Singapore applied on behalf of UIB Holdings for the IPO, which is being arranged by firms including Citigroup, DBS Group Holdings, and UOB.

title: The Assembly Place Debuts on Catalist with Strong Performance and Expansion Plans
body: The Assembly Place debuted on Catalist on Friday, opening at S$0.31, 34.8 percent above its S$0.23 IPO price, and raising S$10.8 million in net proceeds with participation from cornerstone investors Apricot Capital, Asdew Acquisitions, and Maybank Securities. These funds will support the company's expansion plans to reach 10,000 keys by end-2030, diversify into new living sectors, and enter potential new markets in South-east Asia, building on its current 34 percent market share in Singapore's co-living sector.

title: Singapore Exchange Proposes Reducing Board Lot Sizes to Enhance Investor Accessibility and Trading Activity
body: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is seeking public feedback on proposed changes to reduce the standard board lot size for instruments priced above S$10, aiming to lower minimum investment outlays and increase accessibility for stocks like UOB, OCBC, DBS, Venture Corp, and Keppel. These changes, which include reductions from 100 units to 10 or one unit depending on price, are slated for mid-2026 implementation if market supported, with feedback requested by February 13, 2026.

title: Singapore Co-Living Operator The Assembly Place Launches IPO, Targets Rapid Growth and S$88.1 Million Market Capitalisation
body: Home-grown co-living operator The Assembly Place launched its initial public offering of 50.3 million shares at S$0.23 each, expecting to list on the Catalist board on Jan 23 with an estimated post-listing market capitalisation of S$88.1 million and gross proceeds of S$18.3 million. The company, which counts Apricot Capital and Asdew Acquisitions as cornerstone investors and SAC Capital as the issue manager, reported revenue growth from S$6.9 million in FY2022 to S$18.9 million in FY2024, and plans to allocate S$10.8 million in net proceeds primarily for portfolio expansion to achieve rapid growth in Singapore.

title: SGX Sees Renewed IPO Interest and Explores Nasdaq Dual-Listing Following Past NYSE Partnership Challenges
body: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is experiencing a resurgence of interest, with over 30 IPOs announced for 2025, marking a change from 2022's market conditions. SGX is rolling out a new dual-listing bridge with Nasdaq, drawing on lessons from a similar, previously unsuccessful tie-up with the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) announced in July 2022.

title: Singapore Exchange to Launch 20-Year Mini JGB Futures Amid Surging Debt Market Activity
body: Singapore Exchange will introduce 20-year mini JGB futures for trading on January 26, expanding its current offerings as trading in Japanese government bonds heats up. This initiative follows a significant surge in daily average turnover for yen over-the-counter rate derivatives, which reached US$411 billion last April, marking a 684 per cent increase from 2022 levels.

title: Singapore's Equity Market Challenges Investor Perceptions on Growth Stocks Despite Outperformance
body: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) has outperformed the S&P 500 over the last five years, with gains of 16.9% and 22.7% in the last two years, yet local investors remain skeptical of growth stocks, often preferring REITs and dividend plays. Despite this sentiment, companies like Ultragreen AI, DBS, and Ifast have shown market potential, with the article advocating for investors to assess local fast-growing companies such as Toku and The Assembly Place on their individual merits rather than preconceived notions.

title: Singapore Stocks See Net Institutional Inflow, Company Buybacks, and Notable Shareholder Activities from Jan 9-15
body: Singapore stocks experienced a net institutional inflow of S$208 million between Jan 9 and 15, with OCBC, Hongkong Land, and ST Engineering among those with highest inflows, while 19 primary-listed companies, led by UOB, conducted S$11.5 million in share buybacks. Additionally, over 50 director and substantial shareholding filings occurred, including Asdew Acquisitions becoming a substantial shareholder in Low Keng Huat, increased stakes by executives in Lincotrade & Associates, QAF, XMH, and JEP, and Asti proposing a share placement.

title: SGX proposes cutting board lot sizes for $10‑$100 stocks to boost investor participation
body: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) plans to reduce the standard board lot size from 100 to 10 units for securities priced between $10 and $100, aiming to lower the minimum investment threshold and attract more investors. Industry participants view the change as a positive step, though they note it is only one element of broader efforts to make the local market more appealing.

title: SGX-listed pawnbrokers surge as gold prices rally, with MoneyMax Financial leading gains
body: Shares of Singapore Exchange pawnbrokers such as MoneyMax Financial, ValueMax, CNMC Goldmine and Aspial Lifestyle jumped on Jan 26, with MoneyMax up 13.2% on the day, 40.2% year‑to‑date and nearly 330% over the past year after receiving in‑principle approval to move to the mainboard. Analysts note that higher gold prices—up about 65% in 2025 and 15% so far this year—boost the value of the gold collateral these firms hold, driving loan growth, interest income and a strong correlation (0.5‑0.8) between pawnbroker share prices and gold.

title: Singapore's Straits Times Index hits record high of 4,912.46 as DBS and OCBC lead gains ahead of Fed meeting
body: The Straits Times Index rose to a historic 4,912.46, driven by more than 1% gains in DBS (up 1.3% to S$59.06) and OCBC (up 1% to S$21.25), with other blue‑chip stocks such as Singtel, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding and Wilmar International also trading higher. The rally comes before the U.S. Federal Reserve’s two‑day meeting, where rates are expected to stay steady, and analysts project the STI could reach 5,400 by end‑2026.

title: Retail investors pour billions into SGX-listed ETFs and local banks in 2025
body: Retail investors recorded S$2.6 billion of net inflows into Singapore stocks in 2025, with the Amova-StraitsTrading Asia ex-Japan Reit Index ETF (S$216 million) and Lion-Phillip S-Reit ETF (S$170 million) topping ETF purchases and SPDR Gold Shares ranking third at S$141 million. DBS Group Holdings, UOB and OCBC together attracted close to S$3.9 billion, highlighted by an S$826 million surge in DBS shares during mid‑April, while other REIT ETFs and the Straits Times Index also saw strong net retail flows.

title: SGX‑Nasdaq dual‑listing bridge sets S$2 billion market‑cap threshold to attract sizable, liquid issuers
body: The Singapore Exchange’s dual‑listing bridge with Nasdaq will require issuers to have at least S$2 billion in market capitalisation, targeting Nasdaq‑listed or Nasdaq‑ready firms with strong governance and liquidity. Analysts say the size filter ensures institutional depth and reduces execution and systemic risks for both markets.

title: SGX-Nasdaq dual listing bridge offers Temasek and GIC portfolio firms a cost‑effective path to US and Singapore markets
body: The new SGX‑Nasdaq dual listing bridge lets companies list on both exchanges simultaneously, reducing cost and complexity compared with separate listings. Temasek and GIC portfolio companies such as Grab, Sea and Gogoro are positioned to benefit most from the framework.

title: Toku to raise S$13.7 million via SGX Catalist listing, targeting expansion
body: Toku will raise net proceeds of S$13.7 million by offering 65 million shares at S$0.25 each on the SGX Catalist board, giving it a post‑listing market capitalisation of S$142.6 million. Founder and CEO Thomas Laboulle says the listing is a stepping stone to accelerate the company’s expansion and enhance its customer‑experience platform’s profile with large enterprises.

title: SGX explores launch of Asian sovereign bond futures for multiple countries by early 2026
body: SGX held calls with global bank treasury officials about introducing three‑, five‑ and ten‑year futures on Indian, Indonesian, Malaysian, Philippine and Thai government bonds, settled in US dollars and priced on a basket of up to three sovereign yields. The bourse aims to roll out the products in the first half of 2026, with India’s contracts linked to the Fully Accessible Route after overseas investors poured $21 billion into its sovereign bonds since inclusion in JPMorgan Chase’s index in June 2024.

title: MAS proposes regulatory changes for SGX‑Nasdaq dual‑listing bridge as Nam Lee shareholders remove chairman
body: The Monetary Authority of Singapore proposed legislative and regulatory amendments to facilitate a SGX‑Nasdaq dual‑listing bridge, including a single prospectus and earlier retail investor engagement. Shareholders of Nam Lee Pressed Metal Industries voted to remove chairman Joanna Yong, sending Nam Lee shares up 3.1% to S$0.66.

title: MAS and SGX open consultations on dual‑listing rules for Nasdaq and Singapore’s Global Listing Board
body: On Jan 9, the Monetary Authority of Singapore began a public consultation on amendments to the Securities and Futures Act and draft regulations that would allow companies to list simultaneously on the Nasdaq Global Select Market and SGX’s new Global Listing Board using a single prospectus. The same day, SGX Regulation released a separate consultation on the GLB listing rule book, outlining admission criteria and ongoing issuer requirements.

title: Patsnap Mulls Dual Hong Kong‑Singapore Listing While Singapore IPO Activity Hits Six‑Year High
body: Intellectual‑property data provider Patsnap, backed by HongShan Capital, SoftBank Group and Tencent Holdings, is considering a dual listing in Hong Kong and Singapore to raise between US$300 million and US$400 million, with details on size, timing and venues still under discussion. Meanwhile, first‑time share sales in Singapore reached a six‑year high in 2025 as the city‑state allocates part of its S$5 billion equity‑market revival fund, and Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing seeks to attract more non‑Chinese issuers.

title: Singapore market rally lifts STI to record as investor participation widens beyond blue‑chips
body: The STI rose 5.4% to a record 4,909 points as investor participation broadened beyond blue‑chips, with 100 Singapore‑listed stocks posting at least $1 million average daily turnover in January, driven by IPOs such as Toku and The Assembly Place and strong institutional buying in firms like Embracing Future Holdings, PC Partner, Raffles Education and several technology names. Analysts also highlighted AI‑infrastructure beneficiaries including Keppel DC Reit, Mapletree Industrial Trust, CapitaLand Ascendas Reit, Sembcorp Industries, Singtel and others, while the government pledged $1 billion for AI research through 2030.

title: SGX approves reduced board lot sizes for 13 stocks, allowing investors to buy in lots of 10
body: SGX confirmed that 13 listed companies—including local banks DBS, OCBC and UOB as well as Jardine Matheson, SGX, Venture and Keppel—will have their standard board lot size cut from 100 to 10 shares for stocks priced between S$10 and S$100. The change, effective mid‑2026, is expected to boost affordability, with the qualifying stocks generating S$542 million in daily turnover in 2025 (up 30% YoY) and representing 36.9% of total trading activity.

title: SGX board‑lot reduction and calls for bonus issues or stock splits to boost retail participation
body: The Singapore Exchange plans to cut standard board lot sizes to lower entry barriers for retail investors, especially younger ones. The article argues that, alongside this reform, bonus issues or stock splits by companies such as DBS Bank and UOB would further improve affordability and market participation.

title: SGX RegCo proposes broker‑custody model allowing retail investors to consolidate Singapore and overseas holdings
body: SGX RegCo is seeking public feedback on rule amendments that would let retail investors move Singapore‑listed stocks, Treasury bills, bonds and foreign‑listed securities into broker‑custody accounts—potentially effective from June, with Singapore Savings Bonds excluded—while still permitting them to keep CDP direct accounts. Brokers such as Tiger Brokers, Moomoo, Interactive Brokers and DBS could then offer integrated portfolio services, and regulators stress robust custody standards and data‑protection safeguards.

title: Singapore regulator urges listed firms to provide thoughtful forward‑looking guidance despite historic aversion
body: For years Singapore-listed companies have avoided forward‑looking guidance, preferring safe backward‑looking statements, but the Singapore Exchange Regulation now advises firms to offer such guidance responsibly to build investor trust.

title: SGX RegCo proposes rule changes to expand broker‑custody accounts for retail investors in Singapore
body: SGX RegCo is consulting on amendments that would permit omnibus broker‑custody accounts, strengthen oversight of depository agents and require brokers to support shareholder rights, with the consultation running until 27 March; the move aims to shift many investors from direct CDP accounts to broker custody, offering services such as fractional trading and attracting internationally active asset managers. Companies mentioned include SGX, CDP, DBS and Interactive Brokers Singapore.

title: SGX adds three new Hong Kong‑listed Singapore Depository Receipts, including Zijin Gold, Horizon Robotics and China Mobile, from Feb 2
body: The Singapore Exchange will list SDRs for Zijin Gold, Horizon Robotics and China Mobile on Feb 2, expanding its portfolio to 32 SDRs and reflecting a ten‑fold YoY rise in daily turnover to S$12 million across 29 underlyings. The new listings offer low minimum investments (under S$400) and come as Zijin Gold’s shares have risen over 60% to HK$218.60 after a US$3.2 billion IPO, while net retail inflows into Hong Kong SDRs reached S$150 million last year.

title: Survey finds only 42% of Singapore firms plan climate‑risk investments, with low uptake of mitigation and adaptation solutions despite rising reporting pressures
body: Schneider Electric’s survey of 543 Singapore business leaders shows 42% intend to allocate resources to climate‑risk management, with 25% targeting mitigation (renewable energy, green infrastructure) and 17% adaptation (flood‑risk systems) while 58% have no plans; more than 90% have begun International Sustainability Standards Board‑aligned reporting but most meet only 25% of obligations, citing skill gaps and costs, and the Singapore Exchange and Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority have extended disclosure timelines.

title: Singapore's STI hits record high as JPMorgan lifts 2026 target amid strong earnings outlook and market reforms
body: The Straits Times Index reached a new high of 4,923.02 on Jan 27, prompting JPMorgan to raise its 2026 target to 6,000 (6,500 in a bull case) on the back of upbeat earnings expectations, a firm Singapore dollar and dividend appeal, with top picks DBS, UOL and Keppel. The rally extended to small‑ and mid‑cap stocks, boosting trading turnover and lifting shares of companies such as CSE Global, Nam Cheong, Ho Bee Land, Skylink Holdings, Don Agro International (now UpHealth Group) and Mirxes, while upcoming earnings reports and the Fed chair nomination could add volatility.

title: Singapore-China cooperation eases secondary listings for Chinese A‑share firms, boosting SGX presence
body: At the 21st Singapore‑China Joint Council, both sides agreed to support secondary listings of Chinese A‑share companies on SGX by allowing them to follow only Chinese listing rules, a move that has already attracted enquiries and led to recent dual listings such as China Medical System and Concord New Energy, whose shares jumped about 10% on debut; today roughly 100 Chinese firms—about 20% of SGX’s listings—are using the platform to raise capital, expand regionally and improve governance. The streamlined prospectus requirements, acceptance of Chinese accounting standards, and access to Singapore‑based investors and sovereign wealth funds are cited as key advantages over Hong Kong listings.
